@IndranilRoy I think that's where i was coming from. Money is going to be made anyway. Might as well make the profit and the margin official. Make it private so there's consequences for stealing, as opposed to public sector where you can't even check it.

Also...i tell jokes and i'm not that smart. This is just me thinking out loud. 
Ok bye.

Your audits have to all be above water and all your information has to be public. Pharma company gets to recover some risk they've taken during the pandemic, and we citizens get to ensure other's safety irrespective of govts, elections and more.

As an example. If it costs 1000 rupees to make at cost. Charge me 10,000. take 10% to recover your distribution costs, that's 900 gone. And spend 8100 on vaccinating eight people for every one of me. I would like to know who they were and when they got it, digitally.

Might as well make it over the table and official. I am willing to pay a high amount if you can provide what this costs to make ;at cost', declare your margin and make sure a certain number of disenfranchised people receive it for free. If it costs 1000 rupees

I mean let's be honest. India isn't changing overnight. The minute this thing becomes available, along with the frontline workers, and military personal and essential workers getting it for free...every VIP with a friend is gonna pay something under the table for it anyway.

I also don't see it succeeding as a tax, because of how few of us pay taxes. Maybe something private sector where we directly pay a pharma company that is responsible for dispensing free vaccines in an accountable fashion.

I just don't think it's going to get done for those who need it, unless those who can afford it step in and insist and put their money where their mouth is. I don't think big business is going to step in, I don't see the govt funding 1.3 billion vaccines in a timely fashion.
Thoughts on people above a certain annual income paying a decent amount for the covid vaccine, so that the money/margin you put in could provide free vaccines for others?

If you ask yourself how the hell the other side see's this information and reacts the way they do...answer is...they don't. 

The danger of social networks is giving people the news and facts they want them to see.

One pandemic. 

Now this is the place we put all our hate, we've learned the hard way to value the people and real things we love.

Which is not to say there isn't humongous room for improvement in gender equality, entry systems, economics, censorship etc. But when you are on stage, there's not much that can take attention away form your talent. It's yours to own and yours to bomb on.

The thing I love about comedy, barriers to entry aside, is that it's democratic. On any given night, the kid with five minutes is better than the headliner with 45. Your background doesn't matter, and fame buys you two minutes of grace time, and then you all have to bring it.
